newsitem.title: USA: Weak Aug US retail sales present paradox - experts.
newsitem.headline: Weak Aug US retail sales present paradox - experts.

text.p: Weak August U.S. retail sales activity presented a paradox that consumers are spending less as the labor market improves, and the data may up-end prospects for a Federal Reserve rate hike, economists said.
Retail sales for August climbed by a surprisingly weak 0.2 percent after a revised rise of 0.1 percent in July. U.S. economists had expected sales to rise 0.7 percent.
"The third quarter for consumer spending is fairly low following a very strong first half," said James Glassman, senior money market economist at Chase Securities.
"This makes no sense because job growth and income growth are fairly substaintial and there is one thing you can count on -- consumers spend their income," Glassman said.
Most surprising to economists was the timidity of the automotive sales, which rose only 0.1 percent, and were revised to unchanged in July.

"There's a compositional shift (in sales), especially in real terms," said Michael Niemira, an economist at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi. "You moved away from the big ticket items, like computers or cars, to apparel. Because of that shift the overall spending items went down."
